Pardon me, but my guess is that you don't quite understand how evolution works. If you do, then, I beg your forgiveness. See, evolution (in this specific case) can ONLY have an effect on a species when it provides a given individual with an advantage BEFORE procreation. Normally that advantage helps with nutrition, defense and/or attracting a mate. Sometimes it helps the individual survive a bit more until procreation, but typically it has something to do with nutrition (better ability to find food, better ability to consume food, ability to go without food for a period of time or the ability to go without a type of food or nutrient), defense or mate attraction. So, in this sense, now that you understand what evolutionary advantages entail, what technological advancement have you seen or could foresee that would give its holder an advantage in any of these ways? The honest to God answer is: none. In fact, many evolutionists like myself believe that we've stopped evolving altogether. Sure, sure, there are numerous beneficial mutations that occur every year all over the world, but when technology obscures that mutation, it ceases to grant a procreative advantage.  Such a mutation may be passed on to the holder's young (let's say: a 50/50 chance), but unless it increases fertility, then it won't help. Want a better advantage?  Let's say a male, Caucasian British boy, in London ("Jonny") is born with a natural immunity to Salmonella enterica (cause of, well Salmonella poisoning, Typhoid fever, etc.).  Let's say that Johnny survived until he married and produced children. Two scenarios:   If Johnny lived 400 years ago and had 10 children (8 of whom survived passed infancy into adulthood, that's 4 children with the immunity), half of whom possessed the immunity, they would all be born into a time where Typhoid killed thousands of people every year.  Various infections caused by Salmonella killed infants in massive numbers.  Adults died during particularly terrible Typhoid outbreaks.  So, I know I don't need to do that math to show you how powerful a breading advantage this immunity would be.  Greater survival of a powerful pestilence means that more children would survive into breeding age and so on and so on.If Johnny lived right now in London and had 2 kids (all of whom survived passed infancy into adulthood), 1 of whom possessed the immunity, they would all be born into a time where Typhoid (and other Salmonella outbreaks) do relatively nothing to our society.  Sure, sure, there's the occasional outbreak.  And, of course, when outbreaks happen, we have powerful medicines to save lives.  In fact, your odds of dieing from Salmonella even after being infected are really, REALLY small.  So, in modern times, this immunity wouldn't really do much.And here's the deal.  Even if scenario (2) did happen, Johnny's kids wouldn't out-breed any other kids.  Sure, the immunity might be passed on, but there's a good chance that that one kid might never pass the immunity on or might pass it on for just one generation. To be certain, there are a LOT of people still having babies in areas where diseases still happen, but evolution happens over many, many millennia.  How much longer will people be having massive numbers of babies in disease infected areas?  Probably not much longer than the next 100 years.  After that, we will either have population growth under control and most diseases will be treatable, or we will probably not exist at all. Now, as to "technology and evolution", I think that the two are inseparable.  We will begin to actually incorporate technology into our bodies.  We haven't finished evolving, but we've certainly finished the greater leaps of evolution by natural selection.  With the advent of nano technology and genetic manipulation, it's inconceivable that we won't take our evolution into our own hands and make whatever changes we see fit.   None of this addresses the wisdom of such manipulations, but denying that such things will take place is more nostalgia than rational thinking.  These things will happen and they will happen within most of our lifetimes.

Collin's answer has a key point. I've read recent articles that point out that the very size of our brains, which is really what makes us what we are, are only possible due to having cooked meat available due to their high energy consumption. Cooked meat (and cooked vegetables most likely) makes much more of the nutrition value of the food readily available since it is effectively pre-digesting the food and breaking down bonds our body would otherwise have to expend energy doing itself. Effectively that allowed humankind to evolve into its current state of culture and sapience, so you can't really ever take technology out of the human evolutionary equation. It will be interesting to see what society decides is an acceptable level of genetic modification, especially stem-line cells. We are definitely allowing to breed those that 'nature' would have darwined off originally. People like me with a variety of childhood ills would most likely died before breeding. Do we 'fix' people like me via genetic manipulation, or continue to treat the unwanted symptoms/manifestations of the genes? Most interesting to me is that high achievers in contemporary human culture are likely to have the smallest number of offspring. That inversion of natural selection is more concerning to me than the allowance of previously unfit breeders to propagate.

If we're talking on the scale of tens or hundreds of thousands of years (a reasonably short time scale to talk about evolution), we likely won't be evolving new "skills."  Rather, changes to our gene pool will probably be far more mundane.  Here are two plausible examples of traits that could be positively selected for:  Ability to better regulate one's sleep cycle in the absence of exposure to sunlight.  Ubiquitous artificial light has drastically reduced our exposure to sunlight, which is an important ingredient in the regulation of our circadian rhythm.  Disruptions to one's circadian rhythm can cause insomnia, which can impact the immune system, increase the incidence of auto and other accidents, and generally make you a less attractive date.  People who better regulate their sleep cycle in the absence of sunlight would avoid these negative impacts, leading to positive selective pressure on the trait.Resistance to cancer.  Technology — from antibiotics to improved nutrition — has greatly increased our average lifespan.  This has made us more susceptible to cancer, a disease that more commonly strikes in old age.  Cancer is highly resistant to medical intervention since harmful cancerous cells are nearly identical to non-cancerous cells (as opposed to, say, a bacterium that differs in many important ways from human cells).  There are myriad mutations that would reduce our susceptibility to cancer — more active and redundant mutation detection and correction genes like BRCA1 and BRCA2 , for example.  A person who has these mutations is less likely to develop cancer, leading to positive selective pressure on the trait. [A special note on this one: while cancer typically strikes after child-bearing age, with fertility treatments this is increasingly less the case.  Also, even if you die after child-bearing age you can negatively impact your progeny who are still bearing children, leading to selective pressure on the gene copies you passed down.]Either of these could be obviated by technology that helps us cope with the respective negative impacts.  But that would have to happen before selection has a chance to have a material impact.

Q: How does Technology affect Human Evolution? Article  https://medium.com/@manuj.aggarwal/technological-advances-and-its-effects-on-human-evolution-5329718639e7 Technology is progressing rapidly, and it is changing the way we live, work and play. New inventions are happening, and new paradigms are born almost every day. Conventional concepts we are used to as a human race for decades or even centuries are being disrupted by cutting edge technology. Just half a century ago, computers were only surfacing and were used for particular scientific or research work, but today they are found all around us. We see, and experience computing power around us in all shapes, sizes, and types. There are small and portable ones like in smartphones. There are big ones like desktops and mainframes. And lately, with innovative devices like Google Glass or Snap Spectacles — this computing power has also invaded our wearable devices. Whether we like this technological revolution or not — we can clearly see how it is affecting our daily lives. But an interesting question arises — what are long-term effects of this revolution? I am not talking a decade or a century from now — instead what are the implications on a human evolutionary timeline — which could span millennia. Technology is changing the patterns of our life. There was a time when we were very physically active, but now we rely on devices to do most of our work. The changes in our behavioral patterns and adaptations that are caused by these technological advances could prove to be the primary driving forces behind the next stage of evolution for our species. Charles Darwin  proposed that evolution is the change in the characteristics of a species over several generations — which could happen over eons or within few centuries. This process of evolution relies on the process of natural selection. Charles’ theory of evolution is based on the idea that all species gradually change over time. The complex process of evolution relies on there being a genetic variation in a population which affects the physical characteristics of an organism. Some of these characteristics may give the individual an advantage over other members of the same species which they can then pass on to their offspring. This process of continuously adopting advantageous characteristics by subsequent generations is called “natural selection.” ••••••••••••••• . Instead, the evolution is occurring in two other ways Efficiency—Based — •••••• . the human mind is the organ that is being used most extensively in the current world. From complex computations in the workplace to the rapid decision making we need to execute on a daily basis.Transhumanism — Transhumanism is a futurist concept which is analogous to artificial evolutionary process. It involves the studying of internal software of human body and tinkering with it for better results.•••••••••• . In the end, we can say that human evolutionary cycles will definitely be affected by this rapid growth in technological advancements. These technologies have already significantly changed the patterns of life thus making the standard evolution considerably fast. People of all physical strengths and capabilities can live healthy and fruitful lives; making it possible for their mental genes to mutate and create a better result. Additionally, artificial evolution is also not too far off in the future, and soon people might be able to select the different characteristics of their offspring like mental capabilities, physique, and energy levels.

The effect will lead to a choice. Either we will be reckless and likely cause our own demise with genetic modifications if done here on Earth, or we will run controlled experiments elsewhere being secluded from any errors affecting the rest of humanity. There are 2 ways of achieving a new human. Either with integrating our technology with our bodies or altering our very genetics. The fastest way to evolve is unlocking the minds potential. Something very cool is the fact that humanity on an individual level has the capability to evolve further and faster than it's counterparts. Humans are a technology in themselves. If we last long enough, we will be the creators of worlds and their environments.

I would argue that in "Today's  world' new technology has no effect on the direction of human evolution.  Evolution is the effect of the frequency of transferring genes across generations.  In a "natural environment' Those that convey a reproductive advantage are transmitted more frequently.  As others have pointed out, modern medicine and cultural circumstances have circumvented the effects of natural selection among human populations.  Today your genome is much less a factor in your ability to transfer your genes to the next generation.  Only the weakest are weeded out and the most fit no longer possess a reproductive advantage. If anything technology, including simple everyday technology, has made it so that evolution follows no natural direction but is randomized.

Things that many animals would require adaptation to survive, humans can survive because we develop technology. Technology allows us to ‘evolve’ in many ways, only much faster. As a result of technology, there are many logical evolutionary changes we might have undergone eventually due to changes in environment that we likely won’t undergo now. Technology will change, and has changed, what our species determines to be desirable (or even necessary) for survival, and for reproduction, and has made it so that much of it is psychological and superficial rather than physical. Smarter, more confident, more successful, prettier people (and even pretty is subjective) are more likely to find a ‘mate’ and have children. They don’t need to be physically strong or enduring. They don’t need to be tough. What we’ve come to value has changed because our technology handles survival and our evolution is now based around thriving. Mind you this is only true in the civilized world. I don’t know enough about tribal culture to comment on how their evolutionary path might differ from ours.

Durkheim theorised that the process of industrialisation – or the process of technology as we would call it today – has brought about changes in the quality of human life and this is evident from life expectancy rates. In the past two decades alone, life expectancy has risen on average seven years for both males and females in the UK - though the rate is higher for females – with a recent claim declaring that around 1 in 5 UK citizens alive today will live past 100 years of age. In terms of life expectancy, technology is increasing human evolution, insofar that it is prolonging human life.  In terms of whether this advancement is limiting human evolution lends itself to the moral dilemma on whether technology should be allowed to extend human life. In terms of manipulating an individual’s genetics the verdict is still out morally, but in regards to us progressing because of technological advancements, it is widely accepted in Western society that we are allowed to evolve as a race in this manner. However, as any Anthropologist knows, it is imperative to be aware of moral relativism and not make epistemological claims based upon personal upbringing and values – a Western take is not an absolute, or indeed, a universal take.  We have progressed from Durkheim’s industrialisation age where technological improvements reduced output needed by humans and, in turn, improved living conditions and life quality, to Castell’s “information age” in which a more-accessible knowledge-based economy is also allowing conditions to be improved through the ease of knowledge, or content-sharing that has arisen from the rise of the digital world.  Technology isn’t limiting human evolution; rather it’s raising the question of what it is to be human. As we transcend national borders and the constraints of current knowledge, it is our notion of human evolution, therefore, that must change.

Evolution is driven by variation, achieved by changes to our genetics from mutation, transcription errors, horizontal gene transfer, retro viruses, etc.  These are all still happening and greater numbers of humans are alive and passing along these genetic variations which is creating greater genetic variation in the population. All of this is GREAT for 'Evolution' (greater genetic diversity in the human population means we would be better positioned to survive Selection pressures) and probably somewhat bad (in the sense of creating human suffering) for certain groups of people that might have increased rates of genetic diseases. But those same issues could eventually result in surprising new genetics for humans, so long as they don't die before they pass along their genes it is fodder for continued evolution.

Andreas points out "These people have children, and thus these genetic disabilities are part of our natural evolution."  The one thing we have to remember though is evolution is a numbers game. Eventually a species will no matter how advanced come against a challenge that is very difficult to surpass. Due to the fact that genes rarely affect just one tiny part of the body but whole groupings of seemingly random metabolic functions, some genetic disease may be a boon. For example one kids inability to properly process glucose may in fact also allow him to survive a virus that might kill much of the rest of us. There's just no way to know. I also agree with Mark that we need to end up using genetics and engineered cures to help save us from the truly dead end genetic mutations that are almost universally bad for our society as a whole. In short the more people with the more diverse genes equals greater survivability. Developing and expanding your species while increasing survivability is at the very heart of Evolution.

Within bioinformatics we can see that recent human evolution is more rapid than at any previous time. That can be predicted from that a larger population making selection more efficient. The larger population is of course an effect of (historically mostly agrarian) technology. I do not think humans will be able to cheat genes, unless you ethically problematic use CRISP/Cas technology to multiply alleles or genes outside of sexual reproduction. Because individual changes will mostly drown within all other variation that selection acts on. On top of that you have sexual selection that will act to purify against most visible changes. For example if someone changes the genome, including the germ line [why?], to develop eyes in the back of the head it will likely not take hold while getting a permanent Mohawk may work.

Not at all!Our predators have had to adapt; and they are starting to do a good job of it. We have several diseases making strong come backs. TB and gonorrhea, now being able to beat any antibiotic we have. We now have a population that has no immunity to a lot of diseases. Either no childhood exposure or no childhood vaccination. In fact some are so resistant to weed killers that they can't be destroyed with acceptable levels of weed killer.Our bees are dying off.The bugs that eat our plants are getting more resistant to pesticides. Evolution is merely a description of genetic change. It isn't going anywhere, and the "rate of evolution" is a misnomer, since there aren't any units attached to it. That said, genetic changes are happening, due to environmental pollution, mass communication, capitalistic resource hogging, and geographical redistribution of populations adapted to other climes, diets and cultures. But whether there will be an improvement in human flourishing, no one knows. Doesn't look good to me, what with nukes, WMD, biological agents, and greed that prevent distribution of resources to those in need. Sorry to be so gloomy, but that's my intellect speaking. It's really pretty sad where we are compared to where we could be.

No. Evolution will never stop. What people fail to understand is that evolution means change, and not evolution in the literal sense of improvement. According to Meredith Small (1), professor at Cornell, "evolution is defined as change in gene frequencies over time, which means that over generations, there will be changes in the gene pool, and humans experience those changes as much as any other organism". Therefore, evolution is not a path that takes humans to perfection - fitness, resistance to illness, and so on. But a process of constant change driven by the environment. Therefore, evolution has not stopped, and will never stop, but will change us because of the influence of our current environment. For instance, as populations become more developed (in the sense of richer, and more educated), they tend to reproduce less. At the same time, developed nations are a minority in sheer number. As a consequence, in the future, humans will have much more genetic influence from current "poor" populations (Latin America, Africa, some parts of Asia) than from developed populations (North America, Europe, Japan). This is evolution. Not necessarily for the better. (1) Scientific American article, October 1999..

One thing that comes to mind is that machines are improving constantly and are becoming more intelligent and efficient, and as we rely on them to do our work, we are required to be decreasingly intelligent ourselves. Imagine when machines will be self-sustaining, self-repairing, self-improving, and self-reproducing ie able to design and build new machines. We won’t even need to be designing, building or coding them. So, through evolution, we might lose our intelligence and simply become consuming, hedonistic creatures. And we may eventually become so unintelligent that we lose the evolution race and become extinct. I suppose this is another version of the belief that “AI will kill mankind”, but in this version AI machines will not retaliate against humans, or do anything directly to exterminate them.

Technology has certainly altered the process, but I believe our overall evolution will speed up as a result. Now that survival pressures have lessened and mortality rates are decreasing, those who in pre-tech times would have perished are able to live and reproduce. I imagine we'll start seeing a greater genetic diversity over the next several millennia, as genetic variations become more pronounced. The selection process has been halted, but the genome will continue to change. That's just my hypothesis, however. I claim no expertise.

To be crass, our health system is limiting natural human evolution. Since people who would not survive in a harsh environment with wild animals and other threats do survive today thanks to our great medical technology. People with genetic disabilities, etc. These people have children, and thus these genetic disabilities are part of our natural evolution. However, at the same time, our technological evolution is mitigating these disabilities. So in the end, the technology overcomes the problems, making us more evolved than before. But... If we were to lose all our technology along with our medicinal knowledge, I believe we would be worse off than before we started using it. It's an interesting food for thought. :)

I find this topic fascinating and have done some research. While the development of technology is a sign of our own evolutionary advancement, the converse effect is that technology and its ability to connect humans on global and lessen our reliance on remembering things will lead to the advancement of emotional intelligence and perhaps even diminish xenophobia. The extended explanation of this theory is provided by Rob Desalle, a curator at the American Museum in Natural History. Here's a collection of research of the topic if you want to learn more: Rob DeSalle: Technology and Evolution

Michio Kaku had a great post on this subject on Big Think: http://bigthink.com/ideas/26912 He suggests that environmentally-driven natural selection has pretty much ended for humans, and that genetic engineering is not yet sufficiently advanced for people to start actively modifying the genome.

Some people believe the opposite. I can't find a link, here is the core of the argument. Human genetic diversity is increasing because selection pressures are being reduced. People born with genetic conditions a couple of hundred years ago now survive to adulthood. So our genome is becoming more diverse. The increased genetic diversity will result in faster evolution because there are more chances for beneficial mutations to occur and for the person with that nutation to survive until adulthood.

All it has done is allow people with weaker physical constitutions to survive and, in many cases, thrive. It has not so much weakened our population as it has expanded our variety by removing and mitigating the impact of limiting selection pressures. This is definitively a good thing, as it has given us access to some brilliant minds which we would otherwise have missed.

There is no technological escape from evolution. Natural selection and genetic drift are statistical principles that apply to living organisms under any circumstances.  The acquisition of favorable genes and technology will always lead to differential reproduction. Our ability to engineer genes and technology can only accelerate evolution by increasing the rate at which allele frequencies can change. The question I like to ponder is: Will technology lead to speciation or eradicate the idea of species altogether?

Yes, technology is changing or supplementing evolution in several ways, including making some disabilities more survivable, allowing human intervention in reproduction and eventually genetics, and technological and cultural evolution happening alongside human genetic evolution. What is less obvious is that human genetic evolution is not necessarily stopping. With more people, there is more opportunity for mutations, and these mutations can be adaptive or maladaptive in today's life. What we don't see yet is favorable new mutations becoming predominant in populations, but this is simply because it will take many generations.

Natural selection is not the only process. Mutation still operates, maybe more than before due to industrial pollution. Modern technology does not have much effect in the deprived areas of the world so I think Natural selection will still be operating at full speed  in places that have severe environmental pressure.In summary I think technology may have modified some details of evolution but has in no way stopped it. For the first time in my life I disagree with Michio to some extent.

Except to the extent technology changes the natural environment by polluting ground water, streams, rivers, lakes and oceans and changing agricultural land into herbicided deserts, technology is essentially a non-biological activity and does not affect human biological evolution.

I'd argue it already does. In increasing life expectancy and reducing infant and birth death rates it allows people who would otherwise die in “nature" to still survive and pass on their genes, regardless of if that would be a “good” thing or not.

When we started killing other animals with sticks and cooking their flesh, would that be the break from what could be considered our 'natural' path?  I see two possible answers to your question 1: Yes, and it has been doing so since (at the very latest) the dawn of the agricultural age.. 2: No. In a holistic sense, you can't separate evolution into "natural" and "unnatural" - it is what it is.
